title: üíª Feature: Adicionar script de execu√ß√£o local: uvicorn main:app --reload

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
### üéØ Objetivo
Adicionar um script/comando para executar a aplica√ß√£o localmente com hot-reload (atualiza√ß√£o autom√°tica durante o desenvolvimento).

### üìã Descri√ß√£o
- Documentar no `README.md` o comando para iniciar a API localmente:
  ```bash
  uvicorn app.main:app --reload

-   Explicar no¬†`README`:

    -   O comando roda a aplica√ß√£o em¬†`http://localhost:8000`.

    -   A flag¬†`--reload`¬†permite que altera√ß√µes no c√≥digo atualizem a API automaticamente.

### ‚úÖ Crit√©rios de Aceita√ß√£o

-   Comando adicionado ao¬†`README.md`¬†na se√ß√£o de execu√ß√£o local

-   Aplica√ß√£o inicia sem erros com¬†`--reload`

-   Altera√ß√µes no c√≥digo refletem instantaneamente (hot-reload testado)

### üí° Informa√ß√µes Adicionais

-   **‚ö†Ô∏è Aviso**: A flag¬†`--reload`¬†s√≥ deve ser usada em ambiente de desenvolvimento!

-   **Link √∫til**:¬†[Documenta√ß√£o do Uvicorn](https://www.uvicorn.org/)

title: üíª Feature: Criar main.py com FastAPI, rota /health e CORS

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
### üéØ Objetivo  
Configurar o n√∫cleo da aplica√ß√£o FastAPI com uma rota b√°sica de sa√∫de (*health check*) e CORS habilitado.  

### üìã Descri√ß√£o  
- Criar `main.py` na raiz de `api/app/` com:  
  - Inst√¢ncia do FastAPI.  
  - Rota `/health` que retorne `{"status": "ok"}`.  
  - Middleware de CORS (permitir todas as origens *ou* configurar origens espec√≠ficas).  

### ‚úÖ Crit√©rios de Aceita√ß√£o  
- [ ] A rota `/health` retorna status `200` e JSON esperado.  
- [ ] CORS configurado (ex.: `allow_origins=["*"]`).  
- [ ] Aplica√ß√£o sobe sem erros via `uvicorn`.  

### üí° Informa√ß√µes Adicionais  
- **Depend√™ncias**: `fastapi`, `uvicorn`.  
- **Exemplo de CORS**:  
  ```python
  from fastapi.middleware.cors import CORSMiddleware
  app.add_middleware(CORSMiddleware, allow_origins=["*"])

title: üíª Feature: Criar estrutura de pastas em api/app/: routers/, models/, schemas/, services/

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

body:
### üéØ Objetivo  
Criar a estrutura inicial de pastas seguindo boas pr√°ticas do FastAPI para organizar o c√≥digo de forma escal√°vel.  

### üìã Descri√ß√£o  
- Criar as pastas dentro de `api/app/`:  
  - `routers/`: Para endpoints da API.  
  - `models/`: Para modelos de banco de dados (SQLAlchemy/Pydantic).  
  - `schemas/`: Para schemas de valida√ß√£o (Pydantic).  
  - `services/`: Para l√≥gica de neg√≥cio isolada.  
- Garantir que todas as pastas tenham um arquivo `__init__.py` (para m√≥dulos Python).  

### ‚úÖ Crit√©rios de Aceita√ß√£o  
- [ ] Pastas criadas conforme estrutura acima.  
- [ ] Arquivos `__init__.py` em cada pasta.  
- [ ] Testar importa√ß√£o dos m√≥dulos em `main.py`.  

### üí° Informa√ß√µes Adicionais  
- **Refer√™ncia**: [FastAPI Project Structure](https://fastapi.tiangolo.com/tutorial/bigger-applications/).

title: üìù Task: Create System Desisgn Documentation
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Create a centralized guide to **System Design fundamentals**, with practical examples and visual references, covering architecture patterns, scalability, and modern infrastructure components.

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Core Principles  
- System Design basics: scalability, availability, consistency (CAP theorem).  
- Design patterns: monolith vs. microservices, event-driven architecture.  
- Load balancing, caching, and database sharding.  

### 2. Infrastructure & Components  
- Web servers, app servers, and reverse proxies.  
- Message queues (e.g., Kafka, RabbitMQ).  
- CDN usage, rate limiting, and API gateways.  

### 3. Database & Storage  
- SQL vs. NoSQL trade-offs.  
- Replication and partitioning strategies.  
- Storage for logs, files, and static assets (e.g., S3, Blob Storage).  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/system-design`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:

title: üìù Task: Linux Ubuntu 22 LTS Study and migration
body:
## üêß Purpose  
This document serves as an introduction to **Ubuntu 22.04 LTS (Long Term Support)**. It aims to provide essential knowledge and practical skills for beginners exploring Linux in the context of **software engineering** and development workflows.

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Overview of Ubuntu 22.04 LTS  
- What is Ubuntu?  
- Key features of the 22.04 LTS version (support duration, stability, performance).  
- Comparison with other Linux distributions.  

### 2. Installation & Setup  
- Creating a bootable USB (using tools like Rufus or Balena Etcher).  
- Installing Ubuntu alongside or instead of another OS.  
- Basic post-install configurations (updates, drivers, package managers).  

### 3. Basic Command Line Usage  
- Navigating directories, creating and editing files.  
- Managing users and permissions.  
- Understanding the Linux filesystem hierarchy.  

### 4. Software Management  
- Using `apt` for installing and updating packages.  
- Installing snap/flatpak packages.  
- Managing system services (`systemctl`).  

### 5. Development Environment Setup  
- Installing programming tools (e.g., Git, VS Code, Python, Java).  
- Using `bash` scripts and aliases.  
- Setting environment variables.  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/linux-ubuntu-basics`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:  
```plaintext  
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ linux-ubuntu-basics  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-overview.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-installation.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-command-line.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 4-software-management.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 5-dev-setup.md

title: üìù Task: Create Software Requirements Documentation (Elicitation, SRS, Validation)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Centralize knowledge on **software requirements engineering**, covering best practices for defining, documenting, and managing functional/non-functional requirements.  

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Types of Requirements  
- **Functional**: Features, user interactions, system behaviors.  
- **Non-functional**: Performance, security, scalability.  
- **Stakeholder needs vs. technical specifications**.  

### 2. Requirements Elicitation  
- Techniques: Interviews, surveys, workshops.  
- User stories, use cases, and personas.  

### 3. Documentation Standards  
- Writing clear acceptance criteria (Given/When/Then).  
- Tools: Jira, Confluence, or dedicated tools like **ReqView**.  

### 4. Validation & Management  
- Traceability matrices.  
- Prioritization (MoSCoW, Kano Model).  
- Version control for evolving requirements.  

### 5. Templates & Examples  
- Software Requirements Specification (SRS) templates.  
- Example user stories for common scenarios (e.g., e-commerce).  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/software-requirements`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:  
```plaintext  
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ software-requirements  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-types.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-elicitation.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-documentation.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 4-management.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 5-templates.md

title: üìù Task: Create Figma & Miro Documentation (Design, Collaboration, Templates)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Centralize studies and practices on **Figma (UI/UX design)** and **Miro (collaboration & planning)**, streamlining efficient design workflows and team collaboration.  

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Figma Essentials  
- Core interface: components, auto-layout, styles.  
- Interactive prototyping and design systems.  
- Useful plugins (e.g., Figmotion, Content Reel).  

### 2. Miro for Collaboration  
- Boards for brainstorming, sprints, and diagrams (e.g., user flows).  
- Templates: product roadmaps, user journey maps.  
- Integrations (Slack, Google Drive, Jira).  

### 3. Combined Workflow  
- Exporting Figma designs to Miro (e.g., for feedback).  
- Using Miro to document design decisions.  

### 4. Templates & Examples  
- Links to public libraries (e.g., UI kits in Figma).  
- Reusable wireframe and sprint templates.  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/design-tools`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`), PPTX, or PDF (for visual tutorials).  

### Example Structure:  
```plaintext  
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ design-tools  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-figma.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-miro.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-collaboration.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 4-templates.md

title: üìù Task: Create Backend Development Documentation (APIs, Databases, Python)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Create a centralized guide to **backend development fundamentals**, with Python examples, covering architecture, APIs, and vector databases.  

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Core Concepts  
- Backend architecture (MVC, RESTful design).  
- Common languages: Python (FastAPI/Flask), Node.js, Java (Spring).  
- Python-specific:  
  - Virtual environments (`venv`, `pipenv`).  
  - Dependency management (`requirements.txt`, `poetry`).  

### 2. API Development  
- REST principles (endpoints, status codes).  
- Building APIs with Python frameworks (FastAPI/Flask).  
- Async programming in Python (`async/await`).  

### 3. Databases (Incluindo Vetoriais)  
- SQL (PostgreSQL, SQLAlchemy) vs. NoSQL (MongoDB).  
- **Vector Databases**:  
  - Basics of Pinecone, FAISS, or Qdrant.  
  - Python integration (ex: `pinecone-client`).  
- Use cases: similarity search, embeddings.  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/backend`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:  
```
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ backend  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-core-concepts.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-api-development.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-databases.md

title: üìù Task: Create Object-Oriented Programming Documentation (OOP Concepts, Design Patterns, Best Practices)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Create a centralized guide to master **Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)**, covering core concepts, design patterns, and best practices for writing clean, maintainable code.  

---

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. OOP Concepts  
- **Four pillars**:  
  - Encapsulation  
  - Inheritance  
  - Polymorphism  
  - Abstraction  
- Classes vs. Objects, Constructors, Methods.  

### 2. Design Principles  
- SOLID principles (with code examples).  
- DRY (Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself), KISS (Keep It Simple).  

### 3. Practical Examples  
- Code snippets in a specific language (e.g., Java, Python, C#).  
- UML diagrams for class relationships (inheritance, composition).  

### 4. Common Patterns  
- Singleton, Factory, Observer, Strategy.  
- When to use each pattern (pros/cons).  

---

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/oop`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:  
```
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ oop  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-concepts.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-principles.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-examples.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 4-patterns.md

title: üìù Task: Create Agile & Scrum Documentation (Methodologies, Workflows, Organization)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose  
Create a centralized guide to master **Agile methodologies, Scrum frameworks, and team organization**, helping the team adopt efficient workflows and collaborative practices.  

## üí° What to Include  

### 1. Agile Fundamentals  
- Core principles (from the [Agile Manifesto](https://agilemanifesto.org/)).  
- Popular frameworks: Scrum, Kanban, XP.  
- Benefits of Agile vs. traditional methods.  

### 2. Scrum Framework  
- Roles: Product Owner, Scrum Master, Development Team.  
- Ceremonies: Sprint Planning, Daily Standup, Sprint Review, Retrospective.  
- Artifacts: Product Backlog, Sprint Backlog, Increment.  

### 3. Team Organization  
- Tools for task tracking (Jira, Trello, GitHub Projects).  
- Prioritization techniques (MoSCoW, Eisenhower Matrix).  
- Best practices for remote/hybrid teams.  

## ü§î How to Contribute  
- **Folder**: `docs/studies/agile-methodology`  
- **Format**: Markdown (`.md`).  

### Example Structure:  
```
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ agile-methodology  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-agile.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-scrum.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-organization.md  
```

title: üìù Task: Create GitHub Fundamentals Documentation (Git, GitHub Pages, CI/CD, Testing)
body:
## üõ∏ Purpose

Create a centralized guide to master GitHub essentials for the team, covering Git, CI/CD, testing, and GitHub Pages.

## üí° What to Include

### 1. Git Fundamentals

- Installation guide + basic commands (clone, commit, push, branch, merge).
- Best practices: meaningful commit messages, branching strategies.

### 2. GitHub Workflows

- How to create Pull Requests, review code, and track issues.
- Using GitHub Projects and Actions.

### 3. CI/CD Basics

- Simple pipeline setup (e.g., GitHub Actions).

### 4. GitHub Pages

- Step-by-step guide to host static sites.

### 5. Testing

- Integrate tests (Jest, Cypress) and report results in PRs.

## ü§î How to Contribute

- **Folder**: docs/studies/github-fundamentals
- **Format**: Markdown (.md).

### Example Structure:

```
/docs  
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ studies  
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ github-fundamentals
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 1-git.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 2-workflows.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 3-ci-cd.md  
        ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 4-pages.md  
        ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ 5-testing.md  
```
